title: From cold store to superclub: how Fabric gave London its pulse, then almost lost it
text:
I’m staring at a dancefloor that I have known well over the past two decades; I can only hope I’ve aged as fabulously as it has. This is the legendary “bodysonic” floor in Room One at London’s Fabric nightclub, viewed after-hours, with the lights up. Beneath the glossy wooden surface, the tech (including 450 bass traducers) remains cutting-edge: when you dance on it, the low-end frequencies make your spine tingle and your eyelashes flutter.

Fabric co-founder Cameron Leslie, who launched the club with Keith Reilly in October 1999 (the former with a degree in International Hospitality Management and an eye for sharp detail, the latter with a CD/cassette manufacturing company and dreams of creating...
